subject: Re: [junit] Testing singleton patterns
msgSnippet: ... It s reasonable to want only one of an object, but for me it comes down to one question: can I trust my team members not to create two?  If I can, it makes
messageBody:
Pat Farrell wrote:

>Andrew McDonagh wrote:
>
>
>>Agreed, in most case of Singletons, they are created, not because there
>>'has to be no more than one', but because the static (aka global) access
>>method makes it 'easier' and 'cleaner' to use through out the code base.
>>These 'benefits' are often misguided and can be better solved using the
>>'just create one' approach
>>
>>
>
>Perhaps your generalization is correct, but I am the OP, and I really,
>really want one and only one instance of several kinds of objects. Not a
>lot, perhaps 5 or so out of several hundred classes.
>
>I want one MasterControlDaemon, not two. I want one "TrueDefaultPolicy"
>for when we look up a FooPolicy and can't find it, we get something
>more useful than a null pointer. We can subclass, the GrandpaFooPolicy
>can subclass from the "TrueDefaultPolicy" and the FooPolicy can extend
>the GrandpaFooPolicy, but you need a concrete instance of a base, and
>you really only want one of them.
>
>
It's reasonable to want only one of an object, but for me it comes down
to one question: can I trust my team members not to create two? If I
can, it makes sense to avoid the singleton. The enforcement that
singleton brings is the solution to a problem, but the problem is social
not technical. It pays to know whether you have the problem or not.

Michael Feathers
www.objectmentor.com
